Title: Social Cognition in Adolescents: Brain Networks and Social Networks

This longitudinal study aims to elucidate the dynamic interplay between social networks and the social brain during adolescent development. We will investigate how changes in the social brain relate to changes in social network position and structure, and how these relationships impact social-cognitive functions. Our research will integrate social network research and social brain research, focusing on a cohort of 1000 adolescents from 50 classes. Over three years, we will collect six measurements, including social network data from surveys and mobile sensing, and fMRI scans from a subsample of 100 participants on a yearly basis. Experimental tasks will assess understanding others and interacting with others, while ecological momentary assessment will provide insight into daily social experiences.

By examining the neural mechanisms underlying social cognition and their relationship with social network dynamics, we will clarify how adolescents' social brain development influences their social relationships and vice versa. Our findings will have significant implications for the development of interventions aimed at promoting healthy social relationships and mitigating the negative consequences of social isolation or rejection during adolescence. This study's innovative approach will advance our understanding of the complex interactions between social networks and the social brain, ultimately informing strategies to support adolescents' social and emotional well-being.

Title: Social Cognition in Adolescents: Brain Networks and Social Networks

This longitudinal study aims to investigate the dynamic interplay between social networks and the social brain during adolescence, a critical period of rapid social and neural development. We will recruit a cohort of 1000 adolescents from 50 classes and track their social networks and social-cognitive functions over three years, with six measurements. A subsample of 100 participants will undergo yearly functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to examine the neural correlates of social cognition. We will employ a range of innovative tools, including social network analysis, social neuroscience experimental approaches, ecological momentary assessment, and mobile sensing, to capture the complexities of adolescents' social lives.

Our goal is to clarify how changes in the social brain relate to changes in social network position and structure during adolescent development. We will investigate how adolescents' abilities to understand others and interact with others influence their social network dynamics, and how, in turn, their social network experiences shape their social brain development. By integrating social network research and social brain research, this project will provide a comprehensive understanding of the reciprocal relationships between social cognition, social networks, and brain development during adolescence. The findings will have significant implications for the development of interventions aimed at promoting healthy social development and reducing social-emotional difficulties during this critical life stage.
